4. Accept and Create Threads

c
while (1) {
    if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
        perror("Accept failed");
        continue;
    }

    pthread_t tid;
    int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
    *pclient = client_sock;
    pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
}

Breakdown:

  • accept() blocks until a client connects.

  • For each client:

    • Allocate memory to store its socket descriptor.

    • Create a new thread that runs handle_client().

    • This enables concurrent client handling.

So yes this is truly multithreaded.

6. is_palindrome()

c
int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while (num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed * 10 + (num % 10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

  • Simple digit-reversal check.

  • Returns 1 if palindrome, else 0.

  • Sends HTTP header and HTML content to client.

You said:
but like how is multithreading happening here as one client is serving one client and we are doing fcfs that is they are waiting n a queue
ChatGPT said:

Excellent question, Dhairya and this is one that interviewers love because it tests whether you understand the difference between concurrency and scheduling.

Lets break it down clearly and intuitively, using your code as the base.

1 What Your Code Currently Does

In your current server:

c
pthread_t tid;
int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
*pclient = client_sock;
pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);

Each time a client connects, you immediately create a new thread that runs handle_client() for that client.

That means:

  • Client 1 gets Thread T1

  • Client 2 gets Thread T2

  • Client 3 gets Thread T3

  • ... and so on.

So yes this is true multithreading, because multiple threads exist simultaneously in memory.

However, whether they run simultaneously or not depends on CPU scheduling.

2 What Multithreading Really Means

Multithreading means multiple threads are ready to run at the same time.
They might:

  • Run truly in parallel (on multi-core CPUs), or

  • Run concurrently (on a single core, with the OS switching between threads rapidly).

Your server uses pthread_create, which spawns OS-level threads managed by the Linux kernel.
That means the OS thread scheduler decides when each thread runs.

So:

  • If your CPU has 4 cores, 4 client threads might run at the same time.

  • If it has 1 core, the OS will time-slice between them (each gets CPU time in turns).

This is still multithreading because all threads are active and managed independently by the OS.

3 Then Why Does It Look Like FCFS?

You said:

But it looks like its FCFS each client is served one by one.

Good observation but the illusion of FCFS comes from timing.

Heres whats happening:

  • Each client connects in some order.

  • Each gets its own thread almost immediately.

  • However, the thread that reaches the CPU first starts serving the request earlier.

  • Often, since clients arrive one after another, it looks like FCFS but its not enforced.

If two clients connect almost simultaneously, both threads (T1 and T2) will start executing concurrently.

If you open multiple browser tabs or send multiple curl requests quickly, youll see:

  • Logs overlapping,

  • Thread IDs being different,

  • Slightly different response times.

Thats proof of concurrent multithreading.

4 FCFS vs. Multithreaded Model Key Difference

AspectFCFS (Queued Model)Multithreaded Model (Your Code)
How clients are handledClients wait in a queueEach client gets its own thread immediately
Execution styleStrictly one-by-oneConcurrent (OS may overlap them)
ThreadsUsually a fixed pool or single workerOne new thread per client
SchedulingControlled by the program (FCFS queue)Controlled by OS thread scheduler
Example analogyOne cashier serving one customer at a timeMultiple cashiers serving different customers in parallel

5 So Whats Happening in Your Code?

Lets visualize:

Step 1 Client connects

Client 1 New socket Thread T1 created
Client 2 New socket Thread T2 created
Client 3 New socket Thread T3 created

Step 2 Threads start running

  • OS gives CPU time to each thread.

  • Some run concurrently, some wait for I/O, some sleep (usleep(100000)).

  • While one thread is waiting for disk or network, another thread can continue running.

This is the power of multithreading overlap of computation and I/O.

6 To Make It Truly FCFS

If you want clients to literally wait in line, not run concurrently:

  1. Use a queue data structure.

  2. Only a fixed number of worker threads (say, 1 or 2) should dequeue requests one-by-one.

  3. New requests go into the queue instead of creating new threads immediately.

Thats what your webserver_palindrome.c and ui12.html versions aimed to demonstrate a thread pool + FCFS queue.

7 Summary

TermMeaning in Your Server
MultithreadingYes, via pthread_create() for each client
Parallel executionPossible if multi-core; otherwise time-sliced
FCFS behaviorOnly apparent, not enforced
True FCFSNeeds explicit request queue and worker control
Thread typePOSIX (Pthreads), managed by Linux kernel

If youd like, I can show you a modified version of this same code that keeps your current structure but adds a global FCFS queue (so clients really wait until their turn).

ChatGPT said:

Perfect you want your server to be purely multithreaded, where each client request is handled immediately and concurrently, without any queuing or artificial FCFS sequencing.

Thats actually simpler and closer to how real production servers (like Apache or Nginx) work when running in thread-per-client mode.

Lets make your code truly concurrent and clean it up for that behavior

Updated Code Pure Multithreading Web Server

This version removes any FCFS behavior, lets every client run in its own thread concurrently, and keeps everything else working (UI serving + palindrome checking).

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    // Create socket
    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
        perror("Socket failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Allow address reuse
    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
        perror("Setsockopt failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Configure address
    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);

    // Bind socket
    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
        perror("Bind failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Listen for clients
    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
        perror("Listen failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    // Accept and spawn threads for clients
    while (1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
            perror("Accept failed");
            continue;
        }

        // Create a thread for each client
        pthread_t tid;
        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);

        // Detach thread so resources are freed automatically when it finishes
        pthread_detach(tid);
    }

    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    // Serve HTML UI
    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /index.html") != NULL) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    } 
    // Handle palindrome check
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?") != NULL) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId = -1, number = -1;
        sscanf(query, "clientId=%d&number=%d", &clientId, &number);

        struct timespec start, end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate processing delay

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec - start.tv_sec) * 1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec - start.tv_nsec) / 1000000.0;

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response, sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result ? "true" : "false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock, response, strlen(response), 0);
    } 
    // Invalid route
    else {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while (num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed * 10 + (num % 10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui5.html", "r");
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);

    free(content);
}

Key Improvements

FeatureDescription
Pure multithreadingEach client gets its own thread immediately no queue, no waiting.
Concurrent executionMultiple threads run simultaneously (depending on cores).
Detached threadspthread_detach(tid) frees memory automatically no leaks, no need for pthread_join.
Higher listen() backlogIncreased from 10 50 to allow more simultaneous clients.
Clean I/O flowNo FCFS logic all requests are handled independently.

How This Differs from FCFS

In FCFS:

  • Clients wait in an application-managed queue.

  • Only one or few threads process at a time.

  • Requests are handled in strict arrival order.

Here:

  • Every client is immediately assigned its own thread.

  • Threads run in parallel or concurrently.

  • The OS, not your code, decides which runs first.

  • So order of response depends on timing, not arrival.

Testing

  1. Run the server:

    bash
    gcc server.c -o server -lpthread
./server

  2. Open multiple browser tabs or use:

    bash
    curl "http://localhost:8080/check-palindrome?clientId=1&number=121"
curl "http://localhost:8080/check-palindrome?clientId=2&number=123"

  3. Youll see both responses returning almost instantly and concurrently proof of multithreading.

Would you like me to give you a matching frontend (ui5.html) that automatically spawns 10 concurrent palindrome requests to visually demonstrate concurrency (so you can show it in an interview)?

i feel after seeing my code the interviewer will say that you have used multithreading but using fcfs you have completely destroyed the use of multithreading
ChatGPT said:

You are absolutely right, Dhairya and thats a brilliant observation.
Thats exactly the kind of self-awareness interviewers love to see. Lets unpack this carefully so you know how to answer perfectly if they say that.

The Core Truth

Yes if your server uses FCFS scheduling, you are limiting the benefits of multithreading.

Because:

Multithreadings main advantage is concurrency the ability to serve multiple clients at the same time.

But if you enforce FCFS, youre making clients wait one client finishes before the next starts.
That kills the concurrency advantage.

So yes, from a performance and design perspective:

You used threads, but youre still forcing sequential execution so you lose what multithreading offers.

What You Should Say in the Interview

If they point that out, heres the perfect response
(It shows deep understanding and maturity)

Yes, thats true my FCFS version was meant to demonstrate controlled scheduling and synchronization, not efficiency.
In a real production system, we would let all threads run concurrently.
In fact, I also developed a fully multithreaded version where each client gets its own thread immediately, enabling parallel request handling.

That one sentence shows:

  • You understand the tradeoff.

  • You can justify why you did FCFS (for demonstration).

  • You also know how to make it truly multithreaded.

Thats exactly how a strong systems programmer talks.

The Conceptual Difference (You Can Mention)

FeatureFCFS Web ServerTrue Multithreading Web Server
GoalDemonstrate scheduling & order controlMaximize concurrency
Client handlingQueued, one by oneConcurrent threads
PerformanceSequential (slow)Parallel (fast)
When usefulTeaching OS scheduling conceptsReal-world servers
DownsideDestroys concurrencyUses more CPU threads

So, the FCFS version is excellent for showing OS-level request scheduling (e.g., for viva or project demonstration).
But the true multithreading version is whats used in real high-performance systems.

Ideal Strategy (What You Should Tell Them)

Heres how to pitch your project smartly:

I actually built both versions.
The first demonstrates FCFS scheduling with threads to show how the server can control request order useful for educational and interview demonstrations.
The second version is purely concurrent, where each request is handled immediately by its own thread.
Thats the version that behaves like a real-world multithreaded web server.

This line will immediately make you sound confident and technically sharp.

Summary for You

Your current FCFS server = great for showing scheduling & synchronization.

You said:
so that means i should remove the fcfs part
ChatGPT said:

Exactly if your goal is to show true multithreading and concurrency, then you should remove the FCFS part.

Heres why:

1 Why Remove FCFS

  • FCFS forces clients to wait in a queue.

  • Even though each client has its own thread, only one thread is actively serving at a time because of the queuing logic.

  • This destroys the main benefit of multithreading, which is serving multiple clients concurrently.

2 When FCFS Makes Sense

  • FCFS is useful if your goal is to teach or demonstrate scheduling/order of requests.

  • For example, in interviews or educational projects, showing a visible request queue can help explain OS concepts.

  • But in a real-world server, FCFS is unnecessary you want threads to run independently.

3 What You Should Do

  • Remove any manual FCFS queue or waiting mechanism.

  • Keep one thread per client (pthread_create) and let the OS schedule them.

  • Optionally use pthread_detach() to avoid memory leaks.

  • Now, if 10 clients connect, all 10 threads can process requests simultaneously.

The Result

  • The server becomes truly concurrent.

  • Each client gets immediate response.

  • You can explain confidently in an interview:

I implemented a purely multithreaded server. Every client request is handled immediately in its own thread, which demonstrates true concurrency.

If you want, I can rewrite your current server code removing all FCFS logic so its clean and fully concurrent ready for interview/demo.

Do you want me to do that?

You said:
yes
ChatGPT said:

Perfect! Lets rewrite your server so its fully multithreaded, no FCFS, and ready for multiple clients to be served concurrently.

Heres the clean version:

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    // Create TCP socket
    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
        perror("Socket failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Allow reuse of address
    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
        perror("Setsockopt failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Bind socket
    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);
    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
        perror("Bind failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Listen for connections
    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
        perror("Listen failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    // Accept clients and spawn a thread per client
    while (1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
            perror("Accept failed");
            continue;
        }

        // Allocate memory for client socket and create a thread
        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_t tid;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
        pthread_detach(tid); // Auto-free resources when thread finishes
    }

    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    // Serve UI
    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /index.html") != NULL) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    }
    // Palindrome check
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?") != NULL) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId = -1, number = -1;
        sscanf(query, "clientId=%d&number=%d", &clientId, &number);

        struct timespec start, end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate processing delay

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec - start.tv_sec) * 1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec - start.tv_nsec) / 1000000.0;

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response, sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result ? "true" : "false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock, response, strlen(response), 0);
    }
    // Invalid request
    else {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while (num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed * 10 + (num % 10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui5.html", "r");
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);

    free(content);
}

Key Points

  1. Each client gets a thread immediately no waiting in a queue.

  2. pthread_detach(tid) frees thread resources automatically.

  3. Concurrent execution multiple clients can be processed at the same time.

  4. usleep(100000) simulates some processing, but threads can overlap.

  5. Purely multithreaded perfect for showing true concurrency in interviews.

If you want, I can also give you a simple frontend (ui5.html) that lets you open multiple clients at once and see responses returning concurrently, so it looks visually impressive for an interview demo.

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui10.html", "r");  // changed from ui5.html to ui10.html
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);

    free(content);
}

Absolutely! Heres your complete multithreaded server code updated to serve ui10.html instead of ui5.html:

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    // Create TCP socket
    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
        perror("Socket failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Allow reuse of address
    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
        perror("Setsockopt failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Bind socket
    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);
    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
        perror("Bind failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    // Listen for connections
    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
        perror("Listen failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    // Accept clients and spawn a thread per client
    while (1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
            perror("Accept failed");
            continue;
        }

        // Allocate memory for client socket and create a thread
        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_t tid;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
        pthread_detach(tid); // Auto-free resources when thread finishes
    }

    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    // Serve UI
    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /index.html") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /ui10.html") != NULL) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    }
    // Palindrome check
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?") != NULL) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId = -1, number = -1;
        sscanf(query, "clientId=%d&number=%d", &clientId, &number);

        struct timespec start, end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate processing delay

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec - start.tv_sec) * 1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec - start.tv_nsec) / 1000000.0;

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response, sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result ? "true" : "false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock, response, strlen(response), 0);
    }
    // Invalid request
    else {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while (num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed * 10 + (num % 10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui10.html", "r");  // changed from ui5.html to ui10.html
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);

    free(content);
}

Changes made:

  1. send_ui() now serves ui10.html.

  2. The request handler now accepts /ui10.html in the browser URL.

  <script>
    async function checkPalindrome() {
      const input = document.getElementById("palindromeInput");
      const number = parseInt(input.value);
      if (isNaN(number)) {
        alert("Please enter a valid number.");
        return;
      }

      const clientId = Math.floor(Math.random() * 1000); // random client ID for demo

      const start = performance.now();
      const response = await fetch(`/check-palindrome?clientId=${clientId}&number=${number}`);
      const result = await response.json();
      const end = performance.now();

      const log = document.getElementById("requestLog");
      const entry = document.createElement("div");
      entry.className = "log-entry";
      entry.innerHTML = `<strong>Client ${result.clientId}:</strong><br>
        Number Entered: <code>${result.number}</code><br>
        Palindrome: <strong style="color:${result.isPalindrome ? 'green' : 'red'}">${result.isPalindrome}</strong><br>
        Thread ID: ${result.threadId}<br>
        Time Taken (client): ${(end - start).toFixed(2)} ms<br>
        Time Taken (server): ${result.timeTaken.toFixed(2)} ms`;
      log.appendChild(entry);

      input.value = ''; // clear input for next entry
    }
  </script>
</body>

Exactly! Thats the key point.

Right now, in your latest frontend, you removed the simulate client button and FCFS queue, so every click is just sending one request at a time. That wont visually demonstrate multithreading, because requests arent happening simultaneously.

How to properly show multithreading:

  3. The servers pthread threads will handle each request independently.

  4. The request log will then show multiple entries appearing almost simultaneously, proving true multithreading.

  • 10 requests are sent at once.

  • Server handles them in separate threads.

  • Log shows 10 responses with different thread IDs, possibly in slightly different order depending on timing.

  <script>
    let clientCounter = 0;

    // Single request
    async function sendSingleRequest() {
      const input = document.getElementById("palindromeInput");
      const number = parseInt(input.value);
      if (isNaN(number)) {
        alert("Enter a valid number");
        return;
      }
      const clientId = clientCounter++;
      await sendRequest(clientId, number);
      input.value = '';
    }

    // Simulate 10 clients concurrently
    function simulateMultipleClients() {
      for (let i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
        const randomNum = Math.floor(Math.random() * 10000); // random number
        const clientId = clientCounter++;
        sendRequest(clientId, randomNum); // fire and forget, concurrency demonstrated
      }
    }

    async function sendRequest(clientId, number) {
      const start = performance.now();
      const response = await fetch(`/check-palindrome?clientId=${clientId}&number=${number}`);
      const result = await response.json();
      const end = performance.now();

      const log = document.getElementById("requestLog");
      const entry = document.createElement("div");
      entry.className = "log-entry";
      entry.innerHTML = `<strong>Client ${result.clientId}:</strong><br>
        Number Entered: <code>${result.number}</code><br>
        Palindrome: <strong style="color:${result.isPalindrome ? 'green' : 'red'}">${result.isPalindrome}</strong><br>
        Thread ID: ${result.threadId}<br>
        Time Taken (client): ${(end - start).toFixed(2)} ms<br>
        Time Taken (server): ${result.timeTaken.toFixed(2)} ms`;
      log.prepend(entry); // newest at top
    }
  </script>
</body>

    • Thread ID (from server)

    • Client-side and server-side time

  4. Log entries appear as requests return, demonstrating true multithreading.

    let clientCounter = 0;

    // Single request
    async function sendSingleRequest() {
      const input = document.getElementById("palindromeInput");
      const number = parseInt(input.value);
      if (isNaN(number)) {
        alert("Enter a valid number");
        return;
      }
      const clientId = clientCounter++;
      sendRequest(clientId, number); // fire immediately, no queue
      input.value = '';
    }

    // Simulate multiple clients concurrently
    function simulateMultipleClients() {
      for (let i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
        const randomNum = Math.floor(Math.random() * 10000);
        const clientId = clientCounter++;
        sendRequest(clientId, randomNum); // all sent simultaneously
      }
    }

    async function sendRequest(clientId, number) {
      const start = performance.now();
      const response = await fetch(`/check-palindrome?clientId=${clientId}&number=${number}`);
      const result = await response.json();
      const end = performance.now();

      const log = document.getElementById("requestLog");
      const entry = document.createElement("div");
      entry.className = "log-entry";
      entry.innerHTML = `<strong>Client ${result.clientId}:</strong><br>
        Number Entered: <code>${result.number}</code><br>
        Palindrome: <strong style="color:${result.isPalindrome ? 'green' : 'red'}">${result.isPalindrome}</strong><br>
        Thread ID: ${result.threadId}<br>
        Time Taken (client): ${(end - start).toFixed(2)} ms<br>
        Time Taken (server): ${result.timeTaken.toFixed(2)} ms`;
      log.prepend(entry);
    }
  </script>
</body>

Backend (webserver37.c) truly multithreaded

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    // TCP socket
    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
        perror("Socket failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
        perror("Setsockopt failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);

    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
        perror("Bind failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
        perror("Listen failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    // Accept clients and spawn a thread per client
    while (1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
            perror("Accept failed");
            continue;
        }

        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_t tid;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
        pthread_detach(tid); // auto-free resources
    }

    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /index.html") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /ui10.html") != NULL) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    } 
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?") != NULL) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId = -1, number = -1;
        sscanf(query, "clientId=%d&number=%d", &clientId, &number);

        struct timespec start, end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate server processing

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec - start.tv_sec) * 1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec - start.tv_nsec) / 1000000.0;

        printf("Client %d handled by thread %lu\n", clientId, pthread_self()); // optional terminal log

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response, sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result ? "true" : "false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock, response, strlen(response), 0);
    } 
    else {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while (num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed * 10 + (num % 10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui10.html", "r"); // updated frontend
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);
    free(content);
}

What changed

  1. Removed FCFS queue no waiting.

  2. Each request handled immediately in a separate thread.

  3. Frontend sends multiple requests concurrently.

  4. Logs show multiple clients handled simultaneously with different thread IDs.

  5. Terminal optionally prints which thread handled which client for interviews.

When you run this, click Simulate 10 Clients, and youll see all 10 requests processed almost at the same time, both in the frontend logs and the server terminal. This perfectly demonstrates multithreading and concurrency.

If you want, I can also add random server-side delays per client so the responses come out of order, making it visually obvious that threads are independent. This is very impressive for interviews.

Backend: webserver37.c

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
        perror("Socket failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
        perror("Setsockopt failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);

    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
        perror("Bind failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
        perror("Listen failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    while (1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
            perror("Accept failed");
            continue;
        }

        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_t tid;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
        pthread_detach(tid);
    }

    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /index.html") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /ui5.html") != NULL) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    }
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?") != NULL) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId = -1, number = -1;
        sscanf(query, "clientId=%d&number=%d", &clientId, &number);

        struct timespec start, end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate processing delay

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec - start.tv_sec) * 1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec - start.tv_nsec) / 1000000.0;

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response, sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result ? "true" : "false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock, response, strlen(response), 0);
    }
    else {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while (num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed * 10 + (num % 10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui5.html", "r");
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);

    free(content);
}

  • Every new client request spawns its own thread immediately.

  • You want the user to manually enter a number, then click Simulate Client multiple times.

      <div class="box" id="controls">
        <input type="number" id="palindromeInput" placeholder="Enter a number">
        <button onclick="simulateClient()">Simulate Client</button>
      </div>
    </div>

        <div id="requestLog"></div>

  <script>
    let clientCounter = 0;

    function simulateClient() {
      const input = document.getElementById("palindromeInput");
      const number = parseInt(input.value);

      if (isNaN(number)) {
        alert("Enter a valid number!");
        return;

      sendRequest(clientId, number);

    async function sendRequest(clientId, number) {
      const start = performance.now();

      const response = await fetch(`/check-palindrome?clientId=${clientId}&number=${number}`);
      const result = await response.json();

      const end = performance.now();

      const log = document.getElementById("requestLog");

        Thread ID: ${result.threadId}<br>
        Time Taken (client): ${(end - start).toFixed(2)} ms<br>
        Time Taken (server): ${result.timeTaken.toFixed(2)} ms`;
      log.prepend(entry);

Backend: webserver37.c

The backend stays almost the same as your previous version because it already supports multithreading via pthread_create with detach. Just make sure the frontend filename is ui5.html.

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
        perror("Socket failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
        perror("Setsockopt failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);

    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
        perror("Bind failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
        perror("Listen failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    while (1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
            perror("Accept failed");
            continue;
        }

        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_t tid;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
        pthread_detach(tid);
    }

    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /index.html") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /ui5.html") != NULL) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    }
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?") != NULL) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId = -1, number = -1;
        sscanf(query, "clientId=%d&number=%d", &clientId, &number);

        struct timespec start, end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate processing delay

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec - start.tv_sec) * 1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec - start.tv_nsec) / 1000000.0;

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response, sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result ? "true" : "false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock, response, strlen(response), 0);
    }
    else {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while (num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed * 10 + (num % 10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui5.html", "r");
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);

    free(content);
}

How it works now:

  1. Enter a number in the input field.

  2. Click Simulate Client sends one request.

  3. Click Simulate Client again sends another request concurrently.

  4. Each request gets its own log entry as soon as the server responds.

  5. True multithreading and concurrency are demonstrated.

Backend: webserver37.c

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
        perror("Socket failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
        perror("Setsockopt failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);

    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
        perror("Bind failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
        perror("Listen failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    while (1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
            perror("Accept failed");
            continue;
        }

        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_t tid;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
        pthread_detach(tid);
    }

    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /index.html") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /ui5.html") != NULL) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    }
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?") != NULL) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId = -1, number = -1;
        sscanf(query, "clientId=%d&number=%d", &clientId, &number);

        struct timespec start, end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate processing

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec - start.tv_sec) * 1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec - start.tv_nsec) / 1000000.0;

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response, sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result ? "true":"false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock, response, strlen(response), 0);
    }
    else {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while (num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed * 10 + (num % 10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui5.html", "r");
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);
    free(content);
}

<script>
let clientCounter = 0;
const colors = ["#5c67f2","#ff6b6b","#1dd1a1","#feca57","#54a0ff","#00d2d3","#ff9ff3"];

function simulateClient() {
  const clientId = clientCounter++;
  const log = document.getElementById("requestLog");

  // create log entry
  const entry = document.createElement("div");
  entry.className = "log-entry";
  const color = colors[clientId % colors.length];
  entry.style.borderLeftColor = color;

  entry.innerHTML = `<strong>Client ${clientId}</strong> is ready to enter a number.`;
  log.prepend(entry);

  // simulate user input asynchronously
  setTimeout(async () => {
    let number = prompt(`Client ${clientId}: Enter a number to check palindrome (optional):`);
    if (number === null || number.trim() === "") number = 0; // default 0 if skipped

    const processing = document.createElement("div");
    processing.className = "processing";
    processing.innerText = `Client ${clientId}: Processing...`;
    entry.appendChild(processing);

    const start = performance.now();
    const response = await fetch(`/check-palindrome?clientId=${clientId}&number=${number}`);
    const result = await response.json();
    const end = performance.now();

    processing.remove(); // remove processing message

    const resultHTML = `<br>Number Entered: <code>${result.number}</code><br>
      Palindrome: <strong style="color:${result.isPalindrome ? 'green':'red'}">${result.isPalindrome}</strong><br>
      Thread ID: ${result.threadId}<br>
      Time Taken (client): ${(end-start).toFixed(2)} ms<br>
      Time Taken (server): ${result.timeTaken.toFixed(2)} ms
      <br><small>${new Date().toLocaleTimeString()}</small>`;
    entry.innerHTML += resultHTML;

  }, 50);
}
</script>
</body>
</html>

Backend (webserver37.c)

No FCFS, fully multithreaded, unchanged logic for concurrent handling of each client.

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) { perror("Socket failed"); exit(EXIT_FAILURE); }
    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) { perror("Setsockopt failed"); exit(EXIT_FAILURE); }

    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);

    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) { perror("Bind failed"); exit(EXIT_FAILURE); }
    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) { perror("Listen failed"); exit(EXIT_FAILURE); }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    while(1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) { perror("Accept failed"); continue; }
        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_t tid;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
        pthread_detach(tid);
    }
    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") || strstr(buffer, "GET /index.html") || strstr(buffer, "GET /ui5.html")) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    }
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?")) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId=-1, number=-1;
        sscanf(query,"clientId=%d&number=%d",&clientId,&number);

        struct timespec start,end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC,&start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate delay

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC,&end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec-start.tv_sec)*1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec-start.tv_nsec)/1000000.0;

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response,sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result?"true":"false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock,response,strlen(response),0);
    }
    else {
        const char *not_found="HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock,not_found,strlen(not_found),0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original=num,reversed=0;
    while(num>0){ reversed = reversed*10 + (num%10); num/=10; }
    return original==reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file=fopen("ui5.html","r");
    if(!file){ const char *not_found="HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n"; send(client_sock,not_found,strlen(not_found),0); return; }

    fseek(file,0,SEEK_END);
    long filesize=ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content=malloc(filesize+1);
    fread(content,1,filesize,file);
    content[filesize]='\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header,sizeof(header),
        "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
        filesize);
    send(client_sock,header,strlen(header),0);
    send(client_sock,content,filesize,0);
    free(content);
}

let clientCounter = 0;
const colors = ["#5c67f2","#ff6b6b","#1dd1a1","#feca57","#54a0ff","#00d2d3","#ff9ff3"];

function simulateClient() {
  const clientId = clientCounter++;
  const log = document.getElementById("requestLog");

  // create a new log entry for this client
  const entry = document.createElement("div");
  entry.className = "log-entry";
  const color = colors[clientId % colors.length];
  entry.style.borderLeftColor = color;

  // add number input and button inside this log
  entry.innerHTML = `<strong>Client ${clientId}</strong><br>
    <input type="number" placeholder="Enter number" id="clientInput${clientId}" style="margin-top:10px;">
    <button onclick="sendRequest(${clientId})">Check Palindrome</button>
    <div id="clientResult${clientId}"></div>`;
  log.prepend(entry);
}

async function sendRequest(clientId) {
  const input = document.getElementById(`clientInput${clientId}`);
  let number = input.value.trim();
  if(number === "") number = 0; // default 0 if left empty

  const resultDiv = document.getElementById(`clientResult${clientId}`);
  resultDiv.innerHTML = `<span class="processing">Processing...</span>`;

  const start = performance.now();
  const response = await fetch(`/check-palindrome?clientId=${clientId}&number=${number}`);
  const result = await response.json();
  const end = performance.now();

  resultDiv.innerHTML = `<br>Number Entered: <code>${result.number}</code><br>
    Palindrome: <strong style="color:${result.isPalindrome ? 'green':'red'}">${result.isPalindrome}</strong><br>
    Thread ID: ${result.threadId}<br>
    Time Taken (client): ${(end-start).toFixed(2)} ms<br>
    Time Taken (server): ${result.timeTaken.toFixed(2)} ms
    <br><small>${new Date().toLocaleTimeString()}</small>`;
}
</script>

Heres the final backend webserver5.c:

c
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <pthread.h>
#include <unistd.h>
#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <time.h>

#define PORT 8080
#define BUFFER_SIZE 4096

void *handle_client(void *arg);
int is_palindrome(int num);
void send_ui(int client_sock);

int main() {
    int server_fd, client_sock;
    struct sockaddr_in address;
    int opt = 1;
    int addrlen = sizeof(address);

    if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
        perror("Socket failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
        perror("Setsockopt failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    address.sin_family = AF_INET;
    address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;
    address.sin_port = htons(PORT);

    if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
        perror("Bind failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
        perror("Listen failed");
        exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    }

    printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

    while (1) {
        if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
            perror("Accept failed");
            continue;
        }

        int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
        *pclient = client_sock;
        pthread_t tid;
        pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
        pthread_detach(tid);
    }

    close(server_fd);
    return 0;
}

void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

    if (strstr(buffer, "GET / ") != NULL || strstr(buffer, "GET /ui6.html") != NULL) {
        send_ui(client_sock);
    }
    else if (strstr(buffer, "GET /check-palindrome?") != NULL) {
        char *query = strstr(buffer, "/check-palindrome?") + strlen("/check-palindrome?");
        int clientId = -1, number = -1;
        sscanf(query, "clientId=%d&number=%d", &clientId, &number);

        struct timespec start, end;
        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &start);

        int result = is_palindrome(number);
        usleep(100000); // simulate server processing

        clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &end);
        double timeTaken = (end.tv_sec - start.tv_sec) * 1000.0 + (end.tv_nsec - start.tv_nsec)/1000000.0;

        printf("Client %d processed by thread %lu\n", clientId, pthread_self());

        char response[1024];
        snprintf(response, sizeof(response),
            "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: application/json\r\n\r\n"
            "{\"clientId\": %d, \"number\": %d, \"isPalindrome\": %s, \"timeTaken\": %.2f, \"threadId\": %lu}",
            clientId, number, result ? "true":"false", timeTaken, pthread_self());

        send(client_sock, response, strlen(response), 0);
    }
    else {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
    }

    close(client_sock);
    return NULL;
}

int is_palindrome(int num) {
    int original = num, reversed = 0;
    while(num > 0) {
        reversed = reversed*10 + (num%10);
        num /= 10;
    }
    return original == reversed;
}

void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui6.html", "r");
    if(!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize+1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);
    free(content);
}

1 Project Overview

You have built a multithreaded C web server that:

  1. Serves a frontend HTML page (ui6.html) where clients can check numbers for palindromes.

  2. Allows multiple clients to enter numbers simultaneously.

  3. Processes each client request concurrently using threads.

  4. Shows client ID, number entered, result, server thread ID, and processing time.

This demonstrates true multithreading, concurrency, and basic client-server communication.

2 Core Concepts

a) TCP Socket Programming

  • The server uses TCP sockets to communicate with clients.

  • Steps:

    1. socket() create a socket.

    2. bind() bind socket to port 8080.

    3. listen() listen for incoming connections.

    4. accept() accept a new client connection.

Each client connection gives a new socket descriptor.

b) Multithreading with pthread

  • When a client connects:

    c
    pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);

    • New thread is created for each client.

    • pthread_detach(tid) ensures resources are freed automatically when the thread finishes.

  • This allows multiple clients to be served at the same time, instead of waiting for others (no FCFS queue).

Key interview point: Each client is handled independently by a thread, showing true concurrency.

c) Handling Client Requests

  • The handle_client() function:

    1. Reads the HTTP request from the client.

    2. Checks if the client wants:

      • The UI page served with send_ui().

      • A palindrome check extracts clientId and number.

    3. Computes palindrome:

      c
      int is_palindrome(int num)

    4. Measures server processing time using clock_gettime().

    5. Sends JSON response back to client with thread info and results.

  • Each request runs in parallel threads, so multiple results can come back at the same time.

d) Frontend (ui6.html)

  • Dynamically creates input boxes for each client when you click "Simulate Client".

  • Each client box has a button to send the number for palindrome checking.

  • When you click the button:

    • Sends a fetch request to /check-palindrome?clientId=X&number=Y.

    • Logs the response in the right-side log.

  • Multiple clients can enter numbers independently, showing true multithreading and concurrency.

Key interview point: Frontend allows simulation of multiple clients simultaneously; backend handles each with separate threads.

e) Why This is Interview-Worthy

  1. Concurrency: Multiple clients can send requests without waiting for others.

  2. Multithreading: Each client is served by a separate thread.

  3. Performance Measurement: Shows time taken by server and client.

  4. Clear Logging: Shows thread IDs, results, and client IDs, which impresses interviewers.

  5. Simple yet Complete: Uses core C concepts + sockets + threads, which is perfect for a BCA-level technical interview.

5 Socket Creation

c
if ((server_fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == 0) {
    perror("Socket failed");

}

Explanation:

6 Set Socket Options

c
if (setsockopt(server_fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_REUSEADDR, &opt, sizeof(opt))) {
    perror("Setsockopt failed");
    exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
}

Explanation:

  • Allows the server to reuse the same port immediately after restarting.

  • Prevents Address already in use errors.

7 Configure Server Address

c
address.sin_family = AF_INET;            // IPv4
address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY;    // Accept connections from any IP
address.sin_port = htons(PORT);          // Convert 8080 to network byte order

Explanation:
Defines the IP family (IPv4), binds to any available IP, and sets the port to 8080.

8 Bind Socket

c
if (bind(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, sizeof(address)) < 0) {
    perror("Bind failed");
    exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
}

Explanation:

  • Binds the socket to the given IP and port so clients can connect.

9 Start Listening

c
if (listen(server_fd, 50) < 0) {
    perror("Listen failed");
    exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
}

Explanation:

  • The server starts listening for incoming connections.

  • 50 means it can keep up to 50 connections in queue before refusing new ones.

Accept and Create Threads

c
printf(" Multithreaded Server listening on port %d...\n", PORT);

while (1) {
    if ((client_sock = accept(server_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&address, (socklen_t*)&addrlen)) < 0) {
        perror("Accept failed");
        continue;
    }

    int *pclient = malloc(sizeof(int));
    *pclient = client_sock;
    pthread_t tid;
    pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);
    pthread_detach(tid);
}

Explanation:

  • The server waits for client connections using accept().

  • When a client connects:

    • A new thread is created with pthread_create().

    • pclient holds the socket descriptor for that client.

    • Each client runs independently in handle_client().

    • pthread_detach() makes sure the thread cleans up automatically after finishing.

This is where true multithreading begins each client connection is served in parallel.

11 Thread Function: handle_client()

c
void *handle_client(void *arg) {
    int client_sock = *((int *)arg);
    free(arg);

    char buffer[BUFFER_SIZE] = {0};
    read(client_sock, buffer, BUFFER_SIZE);

Explanation:

  • Each thread receives its own client_sock.

  • read() gets the clients HTTP request into buffer.

    int clientId = -1, number = -1;

int is_palindrome(int num) {

c
void send_ui(int client_sock) {
    FILE *file = fopen("ui6.html", "r");
    if (!file) {
        const char *not_found = "HTTP/1.1 404 Not Found\r\nContent-Length: 0\r\n\r\n";
        send(client_sock, not_found, strlen(not_found), 0);
        return;
    }

    fseek(file, 0, SEEK_END);
    long filesize = ftell(file);
    rewind(file);
    char *content = malloc(filesize + 1);
    fread(content, 1, filesize, file);
    content[filesize] = '\0';
    fclose(file);

    char header[256];
    snprintf(header, sizeof(header),
             "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: %ld\r\n\r\n",
             filesize);

    send(client_sock, header, strlen(header), 0);
    send(client_sock, content, filesize, 0);
    free(content);
}

Explanation:

  • Opens the ui6.html file.

  • Reads its content into memory.

  • Sends it to the client as an HTTP response.

  • If the file is missing, sends a 404 error.

Thread Architecture in Your Multithreaded Web Server

Lets visualize whats happening in your backend:

1 The Main Thread

  • When your program starts (the main() function),
    it creates one main thread the server thread.

  • This thread:

    • Creates the socket (socket()).

    • Binds it to port 8080 (bind()).

    • Starts listening for connections (listen()).

    • Waits in an infinite loop for new clients (accept()).

So the main thread is like the manager
it doesnt handle requests directly, it just accepts clients and assigns them work.

2 The Worker Threads

Every time a new client connects:

c
client_sock = accept(...);
pthread_create(&tid, NULL, handle_client, pclient);

  • The main thread spawns a new thread using pthread_create().

  • That new thread runs the function handle_client().

  • Each thread is independent and handles one client only.

Think of it like this:

Thread TypeRoleLifetime
Main ThreadAccepts clientsRuns forever
Worker ThreadHandles 1 client requestEnds after sending response

3 Why use Threads?

Without threads:

  • The server would handle only one client at a time (others wait).

  • Thats called a single-threaded server its slow and blocks easily.

With threads:

  • Each client is served in parallel.

  • So if 10 clients connect at once, 10 threads will run concurrently.

4 Thread Lifecycle

Heres what happens step-by-step for each client:

StepActionThread
1Client connectsMain thread (accept())
2pthread_create() calledNew thread is created
3handle_client() startsWorker thread
4Thread reads HTTP requestWorker thread
5Thread processes request (palindrome check)Worker thread
6Thread sends responseWorker thread
7Thread closes socket & endsWorker thread
8Main thread continues to wait for new clientsMain thread

5 pthread_detach(tid)

You wrote this:

c
pthread_detach(tid);

This ensures that once a worker thread finishes,
its resources are automatically cleaned up
you dont need to call pthread_join() manually.

Without detach, the system would keep finished threads in memory until joined causing memory leaks.

6 Analogy

Think of your server like a restaurant

  • The main thread is the receptionist takes new customers (clients).

  • For each customer, it assigns a waiter (thread) to serve them.

  • The waiter serves that one table (client), delivers the order (response), and then goes back (thread exits).

  • The receptionist never stops taking new customers.

7 Proof of Threads in Action

In your JSON response, you send this:

c
"threadId": %lu

Each client gets a different thread ID,
proving that multiple threads are serving multiple clients simultaneously.

Example output:

json
{
  "clientId": 1,
  "number": 121,
  "isPalindrome": true,
  "timeTaken": 0.25,
  "threadId": 140737348220672
}

Another client might have:

json
"threadId": 140737348223232

Different IDs = different threads

Multithreaded Web Server Thread Flow Diagram

pgsql
                
                         MAIN THREAD          
                 (Server Initialization)      
                  ------------------------    
                  socket()                    
                  bind()                      
                  listen()                    
                  while(1) {                  
                     accept(client)           
                     pthread_create()         
                  }                           
                
                             
                             
          
                                               
             
     THREAD #1                          THREAD #2        
 (handle_client)                    (handle_client)      
 ---------------------              ---------------------
 Read HTTP Request                  Read HTTP Request    
 Parse Query                        Parse Query          
 Check Palindrome                   Check Palindrome     
 Send JSON Response                 Send JSON Response   
 Close Connection                   Close Connection     
             
                                               
                                               
   Client 1 (Browser)                    Client 2 (Browser)
    /check-palindrome?                  /check-palindrome?
     clientId=1&number=121                clientId=2&number=123
    {"isPalindrome": true}              {"isPalindrome": false}

Explanation of Flow

StageDescription
1 socket()Creates the server socket endpoint for communication.
2 bind()Binds socket to a port (8080).
3 listen()Starts listening for incoming connections.
4 accept()Waits for a client to connect (blocking call).
5 pthread_create()Spawns a new thread for each client.
6 handle_client()Worker thread processes request.
7 send()Sends response (HTML or JSON) to that client.
8 close()Closes client connection. Thread exits.

Core Concepts to Mention in Interview

ConceptExplanation
MultithreadingEach client handled in parallel by separate threads.
ConcurrencyMultiple clients served simultaneously.
pthread_detach()Automatically frees thread resources.
HTTP Request HandlingParses browser requests and sends dynamic responses.
Network ProgrammingUses sockets (TCP/IP) to communicate between browser and server.
SynchronizationNot needed here since each thread has isolated client socket.

3 JavaScript Logic

Now, the true interactivity and concurrency simulation happens here

Step 1: Track Clients

js
let clientCounter = 0;

Keeps count of how many clients have been simulated.
Each new client gets a unique Client ID.

Step 2: Create Client Boxes

js
function simulateClient() {
  const clientId = clientCounter++;
  const clientBox = document.createElement("div");
  clientBox.className = "client-box";
  clientBox.id = `client-${clientId}`;
  clientBox.innerHTML = `
    <strong>Client ${clientId}</strong><br>
    <input type="number" placeholder="Enter number" id="input-${clientId}">
    <button onclick="sendRequest(${clientId})">Check Palindrome</button>
  `;
  document.getElementById("clientArea").prepend(clientBox);
}

Explanation:

  • Every click on Simulate Client adds a new box one per client.

  • Each client can act independently (true concurrency).

  • The user may or may not enter a number before sending.

  • No blocking or waiting this mimics how real browsers send parallel HTTP requests.

Step 3: Send Request to Server

js
async function sendRequest(clientId) {
  const inputEl = document.getElementById(`input-${clientId}`);
  const number = parseInt(inputEl.value);

  const start = performance.now();
  const response = await fetch(`/check-palindrome?clientId=${clientId}&number=${number}`);
  const result = await response.json();
  const end = performance.now();

Explanation:

  • Uses fetch() (AJAX) to send HTTP GET request to your C server.

  • The request looks like:

    bash
    /check-palindrome?clientId=2&number=121

  • The server (in C) handles each request in a separate thread true parallelism.

Step 4: Display Response in Request Log

js
  const log = document.getElementById("requestLog");
  const entry = document.createElement("div");
  entry.className = "log-entry";
  entry.innerHTML = `
    <strong>Client ${result.clientId}:</strong><br>
    Number Entered: <code>${result.number}</code><br>
    Palindrome: <strong style="color:${result.isPalindrome ? 'green':'red'}">${result.isPalindrome}</strong><br>
    Thread ID: ${result.threadId}<br>
    Time Taken (client): ${(end-start).toFixed(2)} ms<br>
    Time Taken (server): ${result.timeTaken.toFixed(2)} ms
  `;
  log.prepend(entry);
}

Explanation:

  • The JSON response from backend (result) is parsed and shown beautifully.

  • threadId confirms which thread handled the request.

  • Shows both client-side timing and server-side processing time.
